text.content: This post is for anyone developing a codebase based on the Object-Oriented Paradigm. This post is Language agnostic and the learnings have an implementation across all OOP-based languages.

text.content: Creational Design pattern

rich_text.plain_text: Creational Design pattern

text.content: Â - Builder Design Pattern.

rich_text.plain_text: Â - Builder Design Pattern.

text.content: Introduction

rich_text.plain_text: Introduction

text.content: Consider a scenario where you need to build a highly configurable, step by step initialized object. There are a lots of fields to be initialised and a plethora of flags to be set. You could:

rich_text.plain_text: Consider a scenario where you need to build a highly configurable, step by step initialized object. There are a lots of fields to be initialised and a plethora of flags to be set. You could:

text.content: Create a big ass constructor with all the parameters and flags.

rich_text.plain_text: Create a big ass constructor with all the parameters and flags.

text.content: Set the values manually in your client code using setters.

rich_text.plain_text: Set the values manually in your client code using setters.

text.content: The Builder pattern exists to solve the exact problem. It allows you to incrementally build an object by invoking certain functions on a Builder class which is then responsible for initialising the object.

rich_text.plain_text: The Builder pattern exists to solve the exact problem. It allows you to incrementally build an object by invoking certain functions on a Builder class which is then responsible for initialising the object.

text.content: When there is a requirement to create a highly customisable object whose behavior can be mutated based on a lot of conditions, it is advised to use a builder pattern.

rich_text.plain_text: When there is a requirement to create a highly customisable object whose behavior can be mutated based on a lot of conditions, it is advised to use a builder pattern.

text.content: Code Smells

rich_text.plain_text: Code Smells

text.content: Telescoping Constructors

rich_text.plain_text: Telescoping Constructors

text.content: A class may start accumulating a host of initialisation parameters over time and it becomes harder to initialise over time. Any addition of a parameter has to be accompanied by modifying all the places where the class has been initialised.

rich_text.plain_text: A class may start accumulating a host of initialisation parameters over time and it becomes harder to initialise over time. Any addition of a parameter has to be accompanied by modifying all the places where the class has been initialised.

text.content: Optional Parameters

rich_text.plain_text: Optional Parameters

text.content: An extension of Telescoping Constructor issue is Optional parameters. Setting optional parameters in Constructor becomes awkward and cumbersome.

rich_text.plain_text: An extension of Telescoping Constructor issue is Optional parameters. Setting optional parameters in Constructor becomes awkward and cumbersome.

text.content: Complex Object Creation

rich_text.plain_text: Complex Object Creation

text.content: Sometimes a small business logic is required while object creation. Instead of scattering the logic everywhere, the builder can encapsulate the same, allowing it to be reused in multiple places.

rich_text.plain_text: Sometimes a small business logic is required while object creation. Instead of scattering the logic everywhere, the builder can encapsulate the same, allowing it to be reused in multiple places.

text.content: Repeat Object Creation with slight variations

rich_text.plain_text: Repeat Object Creation with slight variations

text.content: Sometimes you need to create objects with slight variations. Using traditional constructors increases code duplicity and reduces maintainability.

rich_text.plain_text: Sometimes you need to create objects with slight variations. Using traditional constructors increases code duplicity and reduces maintainability.

text.content: In many scenarios, Builder pattern can be an alternate to creating child classes and derived classes.

rich_text.plain_text: In many scenarios, Builder pattern can be an alternate to creating child classes and derived classes.

text.content: Example

rich_text.plain_text: Example

text.content: Suppose you need to initialise a Pizza object. The Pizza is highly customisable based on:

rich_text.plain_text: Suppose you need to initialise a Pizza object. The Pizza is highly customisable based on:

text.content: Size of Crust.

rich_text.plain_text: Size of Crust.

text.content: Cheese types and fillings

rich_text.plain_text: Cheese types and fillings

text.content: Sauces

rich_text.plain_text: Sauces

text.content: Toppings

rich_text.plain_text: Toppings

text.content: Without Builder:

rich_text.plain_text: Without Builder:

text.content:
// Telescoping constructors get messy!
Pizza pizza = new Pizza("Large", "Thin", true, false, Arrays.asList("Cheese", "Pepperoni"), "Tomato");

rich_text.plain_text:
// Telescoping constructors get messy!
Pizza pizza = new Pizza("Large", "Thin", true, false, Arrays.asList("Cheese", "Pepperoni"), "Tomato");

text.content: With Builder:

rich_text.plain_text: With Builder:

text.content:
Pizza pizza = new PizzaBuilder()
    .setSize("Large")
    .setCrust("Thin")
    .addTopping("Cheese")
    .addTopping("Pepperoni")
    .setSauce("Tomato")
    .build();

rich_text.plain_text:
Pizza pizza = new PizzaBuilder()
    .setSize("Large")
    .setCrust("Thin")
    .addTopping("Cheese")
    .addTopping("Pepperoni")
    .setSauce("Tomato")
    .build();

rich_text.plain_text: Actual Builder Code

text.content: Director

rich_text.plain_text: Director

text.content: The Recipe Provider

rich_text.plain_text: The Recipe Provider

text.content: To put it simply, you can extract a set of calls to a separate Director class. The Director is then responsible to orchestrate the order and steps of the process. It decouples the client code from the construction details, allowing you to reuse the same construction process for a known configuration.

rich_text.plain_text: To put it simply, you can extract a set of calls to a separate Director class. The Director is then responsible to orchestrate the order and steps of the process. It decouples the client code from the construction details, allowing you to reuse the same construction process for a known configuration.

text.content: Ad-hoc Construction

rich_text.plain_text: Ad-hoc Construction

text.content: : If clients need full control over the building process (e.g., custom pizzas with arbitrary toppings), let them use the builder directly.

rich_text.plain_text: : If clients need full control over the building process (e.g., custom pizzas with arbitrary toppings), let them use the builder directly.

text.content: Simple Objects

rich_text.plain_text: Simple Objects

text.content: : If the object has few parameters, a director adds unnecessary complexity.

rich_text.plain_text: : If the object has few parameters, a director adds unnecessary complexity.

text.content: âš–ï¸Â Pros & Cons of Builder Pattern

rich_text.plain_text: âš–ï¸Â Pros & Cons of Builder Pattern

text.content: Conclusion

rich_text.plain_text: Conclusion

text.content: So, in this post, we discussed an overview of Builder Pattern and how it can be used to create complex objects iteratively and based on our requirements. The steps to building the objects can be further abstracted out into set procedures inside a Director to maintain consistency.

rich_text.plain_text: So, in this post, we discussed an overview of Builder Pattern and how it can be used to create complex objects iteratively and based on our requirements. The steps to building the objects can be further abstracted out into set procedures inside a Director to maintain consistency.

text.content: Builder Pattern is a wildly popular pattern used in public SDKs(Eg. Amazon AWS SDKs) which allows for custom initialisation of objects interacting with AWS resources in a variety of manner.

rich_text.plain_text: Builder Pattern is a wildly popular pattern used in public SDKs(Eg. Amazon AWS SDKs) which allows for custom initialisation of objects interacting with AWS resources in a variety of manner.
